generated_text:
I'll never forget the day I landed my first job as a marketing specialist. It was like a dream come true – I was finally going to make a name for myself in the industry. But what if I wasn't good enough? What if I messed up some crucial campaign and lost my job within a month? The thought sent shivers down my spine.

As I settled into my new role, I started to notice that my mind would wander to all sorts of worst-case scenarios. What if my boss didn't like my ideas? What if I couldn't meet the sales targets? What if I got fired because I wasn't making enough money? At first, I tried to push these thoughts away, but they kept creeping back in.

It's funny, because when I'm at work, everyone seems so confident and self-assured. They're always talking about their big plans and ambitions. But what if they're just pretending? What if they're secretly struggling just like me? I find myself wondering if I'm the only one who's really worried about something.

My friends seem to handle stress better than I do. They can just relax and enjoy themselves, while I'm over here stressing about every little thing. Like, what if we go out for dinner and I accidentally spill wine on my shirt? Or what if we get stuck in traffic and miss our reservation? My friends just laugh it off and tell me to calm down, but I know they don't understand.

Sometimes I try to talk to them about it, but they just give me advice like "just take a deep breath" or "it's not the end of the world." Easy for them to say. They don't have to deal with the constant fear of failure that I do.

I've started to wonder if I'm just wired this way. Maybe I'm more prone to anxiety because of my family history. My mom used to get really stressed out before big events, and she'd always worry about everything going wrong. Did I inherit her anxiety? Is that why I'm so paranoid?

I feel like I'm stuck in this cycle of worst-case thinking. No matter how hard I try to shake it off, it keeps coming back. Sometimes I feel like I'm living in a perpetual state of hypervigilance, waiting for disaster to strike. And the worst part is, I don't even know how to stop it.

I guess that's why I've started keeping a journal. Writing down all my worries and fears helps me process them, I think. But sometimes, late at night, I'll lie awake worrying about all the things that could go wrong tomorrow. Tomorrow. Just thinking about it makes me anxious.

I wish I could just snap out of it, you know? I wish I could be more like those confident people at work. But until then, I'm stuck in this rut of worst-case thinking. And honestly, it's exhausting.
